Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Resource-adaptive distributed estimation for teams of micro aerial vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work focuses on developing resource-adaptive distributed estimation algorithms for teams of micro aerial vehicles (MAVs). Among the several challenges one faces when designing estimators for MAV teams, the most important one is the stringent resource limitations of MAVs. While in any engineered system the resources are inevitably finite, cost, power, and weight considerations make the limitations particularly strict for teams of small MAVs. In this work, we will develop a rigorous, optimization-based framework for the design of estimation and inference algorithms, as well as for the design of the MAV platforms themselves. Our approach will yield distributed estimators capable of optimally allocating the sensing, processing, communication, and energy resources of an MAV team. The methods to be developed will lead to efficient design tools, and will permit a systematic study of the tradeoff curves between MAV resource availability and estimation performance.

The algorithms and theoretical results that will result from this effort will dramatically increase the capabilities of MAV teams, in domains ranging from scientific exploration to search-and-rescue operations. In turn, these systems will yield benefits that will directly impact our lives, from advancing our state of scientific understanding to saving humans in disaster sites. Additionally, the proposed research plan will create opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students from UC Riverside's diverse student body to conduct meaningful research. Undergraduate students will be recruited to work on new MAV designs, and it is anticipated that such an involvement will increase the likelihood of them pursuing a graduate education. Moreover, as part of an integrated outreach program, we will leverage the nature of the proposed research (flying robots capture the imagination of young minds) to inspire and recruit underrepresented minority students to science and engineering. These efforts will aid in closing the educational attainment gap for underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development of methods for improving the capabilities of micro aerial vehicles (MAVs), as well as other devices (mobile phones, augmented-reality headsets) that must operate in GPS-denied environments, yet require high-precision position and orientation estimates. Our main interest has been in the development of methods that will enable these systems to perform challenging estimation tasks (e.g., mapping, tracking quantities of interest) in real-world environments, using limited computational resources, and low-cost sensing and processing modalities.

Towards this goal, we have developed novel pose (position and orientation) tracking methods, and investigated the fundamental theoretical properties of several types of state estimation problems that arise in GPS-denied tracking and mapping applications. Specific contributions of this project include:

  • methods that allow pose estimation with low-cost, rolling-shutter cameras, similar to those found on modern mobile phones.
  • algorithms that enable such sensors to be used for pose estimation without expensive prior calibration, therefore lowering the barrier to use and experimentation.
  • techniques that allow using environmental features other than the commonly-used point features, enabling operation in a wider set of conditions.
  • new algorithms for initialization in vision-aided inertial navigation, enabling more robust and accurate bootstrapping of pose estimation in challenging cases.
  • exploration of the properties of, and development of consistent algorithms for, estimation in large groups of sensors that collaboratively estimate quantities of interest in the environment.

The algorithmic and theoretical contributions of this project can improve the capabilities of systems operating in GPS-denied environments, in a host of applications ranging from scientific exploration to search-and-rescue operations.
